body:
It's just that I'm slightly confused as to the exact situations in which this change is important. I've been travelling a lot, so I might be stupid at the moment. :)

From [the spec](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1945#section-11):

>  auth-param     = token "=" quoted-string

Now, a `quoted-string` is defined as

> quoted-string  = ( <"> *(qdtext) <"> )

and a `token` is

>  token          = 1*<any CHAR except CTLs or tspecials>

`tspecials` is

```
 tspecials      = "(" | ")" | "<" | ">" | "@"
                      | "," | ";" | ":" | "\" | <">
                      | "/" | "[" | "]" | "?" | "="
                      | "{" | "}" | SP | HT
```

You can have either a `token` or a `quoted-string`. A `token` cannot contain `=`, as it's in `tspecials`, and a `quoted-string` requires quotes around its characters. This makes sense; without quotes, it would be ambiguous if you meant a key-value pair or another token. I bet if you sent 3 or 4 params, it would be confused.

So no, I do not think this should be merged, at least in its current form.
